thread.title: Man dies of injuries from SE Portland apartment fire; another man in critical condition
thread.title_full: Man dies of injuries from SE Portland apartment fire; another man in critical condition | OregonLive.com

author: Rick Bella | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Man dies of injuries from SE Portland apartment fire; another man in critical condition
text:
One of two men hospitalized after a Friday morning apartment fire in Southeast Portland has died of his injuries.
"Our condolences to the family and friends of the person who lost their life in this fire today," Portland Fire Chief Erin Janssens said.
The other man remains in critical condition at Providence Portland Medical Center. Names of the victims have not been released.
Portland Fire & Rescue crews were dispatched at 7:15 a.m. to investigate a report of fire in a one-story apartment complex in the Creston-Kenilworth neighborhood.
Arriving firefighters found smoke and flames pouring from the back of an apartment in the 3900 block of Southeast Gladstone Street .
The fire was largely contained to one two-bedroom apartment, though a downed electrical line sparked another blaze behind the apartment.
The fire's cause remains under investigation. A damage estimate is not yet available.
 Portland police closed access to Southeast Gladstone Street from Cesar E. Chavez Boulevard on the west side of the scene to 42nd Avenue on the east.
More than an hour after the blaze started, Tom Holiday watched fire crews work with a chain saw to remove smoking shingles on the roof of the building.
Holiday, who lives next door to the burned-out apartment with his wife, Tamara, and cat, Mongo, said he was in bed when he heard what sounded like firecrackers.
"There was this weird crackling sound," said Holiday, 34. He also smelled smoke.
Holiday said they have lived in that apartment for about six years, and rarely saw the next-door neighbors, whom he described as elderly. Holiday said they stayed inside much of the time and were assisted by in-home caregivers, Holiday said.
Holiday called 911 shortly after they were safely outside, but at that point, he already heard sirens.
